questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening shortness of breath with walking. He has not had any cough, fevers, or recent weight loss. He has hypercholesterolemia, for which he takes simvastatin, but otherwise is healthy. For 35 years he has worked for a demolition company. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. The patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The risk of thyroid carcinoma is increased after neck radiation or in patients with MEN2 syndrome. Asbestosis is not a known risk factor for thyroid carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis occurs more frequently in patients with silicosis. The main presenting symptom in silicosis is dyspnea and a cough, as in this patient. However, chest x-ray would typically show eggshell calcifications and bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities, which are both absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is not associated with asbestosis, but rather with beryllium exposure.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

D) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is the main etiological factor of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. Although the risk of mesothelioma is markedly increased in this patient, another complication is more likely to arise.

E) CORRECT:

Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignant pulmonary tumor in patients with asbestosis and the second most common carcinoma worldwide. This patient has two important risk factors, namely a smoking history and a history of asbestos exposure. The first symptom of bronchogenic carcinoma is usually a cough, although hemoptysis, dyspnea and chest pain can also occur.

Asbestosis is the main cause of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is still vastly more common than mesothelioma, even in people with a history of asbestos exposure.
questions.hint: Diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes together with pleural plaques is the classic presentation of asbestosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent shortness of breath while going upstairs and walking his dog. It began about 1 month ago and seems to be getting worse. He has also developed a dry cough. He has not had any wheezing, fevers, chills, recent weight loss, or shortness of breath at rest. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma, for which he was treated with chemotherapy and radiation to the chest 7 years ago. He also has hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. Ten years ago, he retired from work in the shipbuilding industry. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 21. Vital signs are within normal limits. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A plain x-ray of the chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Occupational exposure is the strongest risk factor for developing asbestosis. Occupations such as shipbuilding (as in this patient) or those that involve working with textiles, cement, or insulation put workers at higher risk of inhaling asbestos fibers. Exposure to asbestos can lead to complications like pulmonary fibrosis, respiratory failure, and malignancy (especially bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma). This patient's history of smoking further increases his risk of developing lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking does not increase the risk of developing asbestosis. However, patients with asbestosis who smoke have a more rapidly progressive disease course and an increased risk of lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

There has been no evidence to suggest that advanced age is a risk factor for developing asbestosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Family history is not a risk factor for asbestosis, as it is not a condition that can be inherited.

E) INCORRECT:

Prior radiation therapy, especially exposure to ionizing radiation in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, is associated with a statistically significant increase in the risk of mesothelioma. While mesothelioma can be a complication of asbestosis, asbestosis cannot be caused by radiation therapy.
questions.hint: Calcified pleural plaques and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray suggest asbestosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and a cough productive of a small amount of grayish-white phlegm. The cough had been initially nonproductive. He has not had fever or chest pain. He is originally from China and visits his family there once every year. He has worked as a car salesman for 15 years and worked in a shipyard before that for 22 years. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years but stopped 25 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Fine expiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and supradiaphragmatic pleural thickening in both lungs. A photomicrograph from a sputum sample is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation (exertional dyspnea, cough, bibasilar crackles) and diagnostic test findings (asbestos bodies on sputum analysis, pleural thickening on chest x-ray) indicate asbestosis. Patients with asbestosis may develop interstitial lung disease with parenchymal fibrosis, which impairs the diffusion of oxygen across the alveolocapillary membrane, causing an increase in the alveolar-arterial gradient.

B) INCORRECT:

A bloody pleural effusion could be seen in mesothelioma caused by asbestosis. This patient's occupational history certainly puts him at risk for developing malignancy. However, he is currently not exhibiting signs associated with mesothelioma, such as fever, sweats, weight loss, or fatigue. Also, there are no signs on the physical exam or imaging that indicate effusion in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive interferon-γ release assay would indicate infection with M. tuberculosis. This patient has a considerable risk of tuberculosis since he is originally from China, a country with a high incidence of the disease, and visits yearly. However, active pulmonary tuberculosis typically manifests with a productive cough (possibly hemoptysis), as well as fever and weight loss. Furthermore, pleural thickening and the absence of hilar lymphadenopathy or cavitation on x-ray are not consistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung capacity can be increased in obstructive lung diseases such as emphysema. This patient may have mild obstructive lung changes from his smoking history. However, the findings on x-ray and from the sputum sample indicate a restrictive disease that would result in a decreased lung capacity.

E) INCORRECT:

A concave flow-volume loop is seen in obstructive lung disease and is due to increased resistance during expiration. In a patient with suspected asbestosis, the flow-volume loop would be expected to show a restrictive pattern. This means it would have a normal shape, but a decreased overall volume.

F) INCORRECT:

Diffusing capacity (DLCO) is increased when gases like oxygen, or carbon monoxide in the pulmonary test, are easily transported across the capillary membrane within the alveoli. This can be seen in bronchial asthma, obesity, and polycythemia vera. However, this patient's interstitial lung disease causes fibrosis and therefore thickening of capillary membrane, which reduces diffusing capacity.
questions.hint: This patient sputum sample shows an elongated, yellow rod (i.e., an asbestos body).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 9-month history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-inspiratory crackles. There is digital clubbing. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 97% and a total lung capacity of 70%. An x-ray of the chest shows small bilateral reticular opacities, predominantly in the lower lobes. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on lung biopsy is shown. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Shipbuilders might be exposed to asbestos, as it is a highly resilient material that is an optimal insulator and was widely used before its dangers were known. Other patients at high risk for occupational exposure to asbestos include construction workers (plumbing, roofing, insulation) and firefighters (heat-resistant clothing). The incidence of asbestosis is dependent on cumulative exposure. While asbestosis usually affects the lower lobes, other pneumoconioses (e.g., due to silica, coal, beryllium) tend to affect the upper lobes of the lungs. The most commonly associated malignancies of asbestosis are bronchogenic carcinoma, followed by mesothelioma.

Calcified (ivory-white) or fibrous pleural plaques are pathognomonic of asbestosis.
Image Description:

Gross specimen of diaphragmatic pleura

Partially confluent, fibrous plaques with a verrucous appearance are visible.

Histological examination revealed pleuropulmonary asbestosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Workers in aerospace manufacturing are often exposed to beryllium alloys, which can cause berylliosis after high-grade exposure. Although berylliosis can manifest with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, chest x-ray would show fine nodular opacities in the upper lung zones rather than the lower lungs. Moreover, lung biopsy would reveal non-caseating granulomas similar to those seen in sarcoidosis, not ferruginous bodies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy specimen (high magnification)

Purple-stained epithelioid cells forming circular patterns (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.

This pattern is characteristic of noncaseating granulomas, which are a typical finding in sarcoidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cattle farmers are chronically exposed to organic dust (e.g., from molds, animal proteins) and are at risk for chronic hypersensitivity pneumonia, which is characterized by slowly progressive dyspnea, bilateral crackles, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, which is also seen here. However, the chest x-ray would show ground-glass opacities with honeycombing (fibrotic changes) and lung biopsy would reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells, not ferruginous bodies.
Image Description:

H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

D) INCORRECT:

Workers exposed to silica dust (e.g., in sandblasting, mining, casting metals) are at risk for silicosis, which usually manifests with a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. X-ray findings in silicosis typically include hilar eggshell calcifications and nodular opacities in the upper lobes rather than the lower lobes. After long-term exposure to silica dust, histopathological examination of the lung typically shows silicotic nodules, which are composed of collagen fibers surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes, and, possibly, intra- or extracellular birefringent silica particles.

E) INCORRECT:

Coal miners are at increased risk of coal workers' pneumoconiosis, which is caused by chronic occupational exposure to carbon dust. Although it can manifest with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, the chest x-ray would show fine nodular opacities in the upper lung zones rather than the lower lungs. Furthermore, lung biopsy would reveal macrophages laden with carbon, not iron-coated asbestos fibers.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain, low magnification)

Accumulations of carbon particles (anthracotic pigment) can be seen in the lung tissue. Some of the pigment can be found in pigment-laden macrophages. Also, collagenous fibrosis is predominant throughout the lung tissue.

This appearance is diagnostic of pneumoconiosis (e.g., coal workers' pneumoconiosis).
questions.hint: The patient presents with chronic, progressive dyspnea and shows a restrictive pattern of lung disease on pulmonary function tests (normal to increased FEV1:FVC ratio, decreased TLC). The photomicrograph of the lung biopsy specimen shows several dumbbell-shaped ferruginous bodies, which are collections of iron and protein-coating asbestos fibers.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, and a 6.6-kg (14.5-lb) weight loss. For the past week, he has had blood-tinged sputum. He is a retired demolition foreman. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. A CT scan of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and circumferential pleural thickening with calcifications on the left hemithorax. Pathologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the thickened tissue is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Synaptophysin-positive dark blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scarce cytoplasm
Calretinin-positive polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli
Napsin-positive cells in an acinar growth pattern with intracytoplasmatic mucin
Keratin-producing large polygonal cells with intercellular bridges
Large polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli and abundant pale cytoplasm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These findings describe Kulchitsky cells, which are characteristic of small cell lung carcinoma. Synaptophysin is a biomarker found in tumors with neuroendocrine differentiation. The abundance of small, dark blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (salt and pepper appearance) and scarce cytoplasm indicates rapid growth and metabolic activity. Other immunohistochemical findings of SCLC include a positive chromogranin A and neuron-specific enolase stain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

B) CORRECT:

These findings describe the histopathologic appearance of mesothelioma. Calretinin is a biomarker found in both benign and malignant tissue of mesothelial origin. Mesothelial cells are often polygonal in shape and have long, slender microvilli, which can be seen on electron microscopy, and psammoma bodies.

The most common malignancy associated with asbestosis is bronchogenic carcinoma, not mesothelioma. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is not as specific for asbestosis, since almost all cases of pleural mesothelioma arise secondary to asbestos exposure, usually after a long latency period of 20–40 years.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of visceral pleura (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Numerous epithelioid cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli can be seen at the visceral pleural surface in the upper part of the image. They represent a dysplastic in situ lesion (green overlay). Cells with the same morphology can also be seen below the basement membrane (marked by black line), representing an invasive component (white overlay).

The diagnosis of an epithelioid mesothelioma with a corresponding mesothelioma in situ lesion was confirmed by immunohistochemistry (calretinin and WT1 positive, BerEP4 negative).

C) INCORRECT:

These findings describe the histopathologic appearance of well-differentiated lung adenocarcinoma, a non-small cell lung cancer. This tumor has a glandular pattern and stains positive for mucin. Other biomarkers for lung adenocarcinoma include napsin A and TTF-1.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

These findings describe the histopathologic appearance of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung, a non-small cell lung cancer that is preceded by years of squamous cell metaplasia. SCCs produce keratin pearls, a characteristic histopathologic finding; keratin is a marker of tumors with squamous epithelial differentiation. The presence of intercellular bridges (desmosomes) between numerous polygonal cells is also characteristic of SCC.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue sample (H&E stain)

In the center of the image is a nest of large, keratin-containing cells. The cells are arranged in sheets and show intercellular bridging. The margins of the keratinized cell nest are beginning to show keratinization as well, suggesting that the tumor is spreading. Numerous glycogen-containing clear cells can be seen in the upper left quadrant of the image.

E) INCORRECT:

These findings describe the histopathologic appearance of large cell carcinoma, a non-small cell lung cancer. This malignancy is characterized by large, pleomorphic cells that can occasionally secrete β-hCG.
questions.hint: This man, whose former occupation carries a high risk of chronic inhalational exposure to asbestos, presents with weight loss, dyspnea, cough with hemoptysis, and circumferential pleural thickening on CT scan. The occupational history, symptoms, and findings are highly suggestive of malignant pleural mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening exertional dyspnea and a persistent dry cough. For 37 years he has worked in a naval shipyard. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and pleural reticulonodular opacities. A CT scan of the chest shows pleural plaques and subpleural linear opacities. The patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignant pulmonary tumor in patients with asbestosis and the second most common carcinoma worldwide. This patient has two important risk factors, primarily a smoking history and a history of asbestos exposure. The first symptom of bronchogenic carcinoma is usually a cough, although hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest pain can also occur. Asbestosis is the main cause of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is still vastly more common than mesothelioma, even in people with a history of asbestos exposure.
Image Description:

Chest X-ray (PA view)

Bilateral pleural plaques (indicated by arrowheads), some of which are densely calcified, appear as curvilinear and irregular opacities.

The lung opacities (green overlay) raised concern for lung cancer, but biopsy established a diagnosis of cryptococcus infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillomas are a form of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis that can occur in a number of lung conditions, including silicosis, pulmonary sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis. It is not associated with asbestosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis occurs more frequently in patients with silicosis, which primarily presents with dyspnea and a cough, as in this patient. However, chest x-ray would typically show eggshell calcifications and bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities, which are both absent here.

D) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is the main etiological factor of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. Although the risk of mesothelioma is markedly increased in this patient, another complication is more likely to arise.

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous emphysema leading to spontaneous pneumothorax is a known complication of aluminosis, a form of pneumoconiosis, which results from chronic inhalation of aluminum dust, most often in welders. This pneumoconiosis is very rare, and while it may present with dyspnea on exertion and cough, a CT scan of the chest would demonstrate small cystic radiolucencies (honeycombing).
questions.hint: The x-ray findings of diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and pleural reticulonodular opacities, along with the CT finding of pleural plaques, is a classic radiographic presentation of asbestosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of chest pain, progressive shortness of breath with exertion, and a 5-kg (11-Ib) weight loss. The patient also reports daily coughing in the morning that has been worsening over the past few months. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and gout. She worked as an electrician for 35 years and retired 2 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include a tiotropium inhaler and allopurinol. She appears pale and thin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/79 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows asymmetrical chest wall expansion during respiration. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secondary tuberculosis can also manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, this patient presents with asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion, which are uncommon in this condition. In addition, a CT scan of a patient with secondary tuberculosis typically shows thick-walled cavitary lesions, centrilobular nodules, and patchy consolidations of the upper lobes rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, this patient has no known history of Mycobacteria exposure and does not have any risk factors (e.g., HIV infection, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus) for tuberculosis reactivation.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

B) CORRECT:

Mesothelioma is the second most common malignancy (after bronchogenic carcinoma) caused by chronic asbestos exposure, which can occur in individuals working in the insulation industry. Patients typically present with characteristic symptoms of pleural involvement (e.g., chest pain, exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, dullness on chest percussion, decreased breath sounds, asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss). A CT scan of the chest usually shows diffuse pleural thickening with decreased ipsilateral lung volumes, which is also seen here. Although surgery and chemotherapy may provide symptomatic relief, the prognosis remains poor with a mean survival of approx. 12 months after diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to silica dust can result in the development of interstitial lung disease, which can manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, this patient presents with asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion, which are uncommon in this condition. Patients with chronic silicosis typically present with diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities and bilateral perihilar calcifications (eggshell calcifications) on chest CT scan rather than diffuse pleural thickening on the left, which is seen here. Furthermore, this patient used to work in the wiring industry, which does not involve silica exposure.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspnea

There are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.

Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A lung abscess can manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, weight loss, and dullness on chest percussion. However, asymmetrical chest expansion during respiration is uncommon, and patients typically present with fever, foul-smelling purulent sputum, and increased rather than decreased breath sounds. In addition, a CT scan usually shows thick-walled, intraparenchymal cavities with air-fluid levels rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, lung abscesses most commonly develop as a result of aspiration, for which this patient has no risk factors.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with pneumonia and lung abscesses

Two thick-walled cavitary lesions (green overlay) are seen in the right middle lobe. A sharp air-fluid level is visible within the anterior cavity. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red overlays) are present within the surrounding consolidation.

E) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) can develop in individuals with a prolonged history of smoking and chronic exposure to asbestos. Although SCLC can cause chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss, the tumor typically manifests with an irregular, central mass with perihilar node involvement rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here.
Image Description:

CT chest (without contrast; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with small cell lung carcinoma

A lobulated central left upper lobe mass (green overlay) is accompanied by bulky lymphadenopathy (examples indicated by red overlay).

Small cell lung carcinoma generally presents as a central mass.

C: cystic lung lesion
questions.hint: Patients with a history of occupational exposure (e.g., handling old electrical insulation) are at increased risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with intermittent shortness of breath while going upstairs. It began about 1 month ago and seems to be getting worse. He has also developed a dry cough. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma, for which he was treated with chemotherapy and radiation to the chest 7 years ago. Ten years ago, he retired from work in the shipbuilding industry. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 21. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A plain x-ray of the chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?

A) CORRECT:

Occupational exposure is the strongest risk factor for developing asbestosis. Occupations such as shipbuilding (as in this patient) or those that involve working with textiles, cement, or insulation put workers at higher risk of inhaling asbestos fibers. Exposure to asbestos can lead to complications like pulmonary fibrosis, respiratory failure, and malignancy (especially bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma). This patient's history of smoking further increases his risk of developing lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking does not increase the risk of developing asbestosis. However, patients with asbestosis who smoke have a more rapidly progressive disease course and an increased risk of lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

There has been no evidence to suggest that advanced age is a risk factor for developing asbestosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Family history is not a risk factor for asbestosis, as it is not a condition that can be inherited.

E) INCORRECT:

Prior radiation therapy, especially exposure to ionizing radiation in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, is associated with a statistically significant increase in the risk of mesothelioma. While mesothelioma can be a complication of asbestosis, asbestosis cannot be caused by radiation therapy.

For 35 years he has worked for a demolition company. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. The patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?

A) INCORRECT:

The risk of thyroid carcinoma is increased after neck radiation or in patients with MEN2 syndrome. Asbestosis is not a known risk factor for thyroid carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is not associated with asbestosis, but rather with beryllium exposure.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

Asbestosis is the main etiological factor of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. Although the risk of mesothelioma is markedly increased in this patient, another complication is more likely to arise.

E) CORRECT:

Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignant pulmonary tumor in patients with asbestosis and the second most common carcinoma worldwide. This patient has two important risk factors, namely a smoking history and a history of asbestos exposure. The first symptom of bronchogenic carcinoma is usually a cough, although hemoptysis, dyspnea and chest pain can also occur.

Asbestosis is the main cause of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is still vastly more common than mesothelioma, even in people with a history of asbestos exposure.
questions.hint: Diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes together with pleural plaques is the classic presentation of asbestosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-month history of chest pain, progressive shortness of breath with exertion, and a 5-kg (11-Ib) weight loss. The patient also reports daily coughing in the morning that has been worsening over the past few months. She worked as an electrician for 35 years and retired 2 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/79 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows asymmetric chest wall expansion during respiration. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung. A CT scan of the chest shows diffuse nodular pleural thickening on one side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secondary tuberculosis can also manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, asymmetric chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion are uncommon. In addition, a CT scan of a patient with secondary tuberculosis typically shows thick-walled cavitary lesions, centrilobular nodules, and patchy consolidations of the upper lobes rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, this patient has no known history of Mycobacteria exposure and does not have any risk factors (e.g., HIV infection, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus) for tuberculosis reactivation.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

B) CORRECT:

Mesothelioma is the second most common malignancy (after bronchogenic carcinoma) associated with chronic asbestos exposure, which can occur in individuals working in the insulation industry. Patients typically present with characteristic symptoms of pleural involvement (e.g., chest pain, exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, dullness on chest percussion, decreased breath sounds, asymmetric chest expansion during respiration) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss). A CT scan of the chest usually shows diffuse pleural thickening with decreased ipsilateral lung volumes, which is also seen here. Although surgery and chemotherapy may provide symptomatic relief, the prognosis remains poor with a mean survival of approx. 12 months after diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to silica dust can result in the development of interstitial lung disease, which can also manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. However, asymmetric chest expansion during respiration, unilaterally decreased breath sounds, and dullness on chest percussion are uncommon. Patients with chronic silicosis typically present with diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities and bilateral perihilar calcifications (eggshell calcifications) on chest CT scan rather than diffuse pleural thickening on the left, which is seen here. Furthermore, this patient used to work in the wiring industry, which is not associated with silica exposure.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspnea

There are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.

Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A lung abscess can also manifest with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, weight loss, and dullness on chest percussion. However, asymmetric chest expansion during respiration is uncommon and patients typically present with fever, foul-smelling purulent sputum, and increased rather than decreased breath sounds. In addition, a CT scan usually shows thick-walled, intraparenchymal cavities with air-fluid levels rather than the unilateral nodular pleural thickening seen here. Furthermore, lung abscesses most commonly develop as a result of aspiration, for which this patient has no risk factors.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with pneumonia and lung abscesses

Two thick-walled cavitary lesions (green overlay) are seen in the right middle lobe. A sharp air-fluid level is visible within the anterior cavity. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red overlays) are present within the surrounding consolidation.

E) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) can develop in individuals with a prolonged history of smoking and chronic exposure to asbestos. Although SCLC can cause chest pain, exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss, the tumor typically manifests with an irregular, central mass with perihilar node involvement rather than unilateral nodular pleural thickening.
Image Description:

CT chest (without contrast; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with small cell lung carcinoma

A lobulated central left upper lobe mass (green overlay) is accompanied by bulky lymphadenopathy (examples indicated by red overlay).

Small cell lung carcinoma generally presents as a central mass.

C: cystic lung lesion
questions.hint: Patients with a history of occupational exposure (e.g., handling old electrical insulation) are at increased risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: You are seeing a 70-year-old man who presents with intermittent shortness of breath when climbing stairs, which began about 1 month ago and is worsening. He has also developed a dry cough. His history includes Hodgkin lymphoma treated with chemotherapy and chest radiation 7 years ago. He retired from work in the shipbuilding industry 10 years ago. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since age 21. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A chest x-ray shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. Which one of the following is the strongest risk factor for his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking does not increase the risk of developing asbestosis. However, patients with asbestosis who smoke have a more rapidly progressive disease course and an increased risk of lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Prior radiation therapy, especially exposure to ionizing radiation in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, is associated with a statistically significant increase in the risk of mesothelioma. While mesothelioma can be a complication of asbestosis, asbestosis cannot be caused by radiation therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Occupational exposure is the strongest risk factor for developing asbestosis. Occupations such as shipbuilding (as in this patient) or those that involve working with textiles, cement, or insulation put workers at higher risk of inhaling asbestos fibers. Exposure to asbestos can lead to complications like pulmonary fibrosis, respiratory failure, and malignancy (especially bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma). This patient's history of smoking further increases his risk of developing lung cancer.

Key learning point: Occupational exposure to asbestos, especially in industries like shipbuilding, is the primary risk factor for developing asbestosis.

D) INCORRECT:

There has been no evidence to suggest that advanced age is a risk factor for developing asbestosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Family history is not a risk factor for asbestosis, as it is not a condition that can be inherited.
questions.hint: Calcified pleural plaques and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray suggest asbestosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion. He denies cough, fever, or recent weight loss. He has worked for a demolition company for 35 years and has a 33-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On pulmonary examination, you hear fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. This patient is most likely to develop which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is not associated with asbestosis, but rather with beryllium exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis occurs more frequently in patients with silicosis. The main presenting symptom in silicosis is dyspnea and a cough, as in this patient. However, chest x-ray would typically show eggshell calcifications and bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities, which are both absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of thyroid carcinoma is increased after neck radiation or in patients with MEN2 syndrome. Asbestosis is not a known risk factor for thyroid carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignant pulmonary tumor in patients with asbestosis and the second most common carcinoma worldwide. This patient has two important risk factors, namely a smoking history and a history of asbestos exposure. The first symptom of bronchogenic carcinoma is usually a cough, although hemoptysis, dyspnea and chest pain can also occur.

Asbestosis is the main cause of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is still vastly more common than mesothelioma, even in people with a history of asbestos exposure.

Key learning point: Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignancy in individuals with asbestosis, especially when combined with a history of cigarette smoking.

E) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is the main etiological factor of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. Although the risk of mesothelioma is markedly increased in this patient, another complication is more likely to arise.
questions.hint: Diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes together with pleural plaques is the classic presentation of asbestosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the ED with right-sided chest discomfort. He reports progressive shortness of breath and right-sided chest discomfort worsening over several weeks. He worked for 25 years as a shipyard insulation installer and quit 20 years ago. He denies fever or cough. Vital signs are BP, 136/78 mm Hg; P, 98; R, 24; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F); oxygen saturation, 91% on room air. Chest x-ray shows blunting of the right costophrenic angle and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform diagnostic thoracentesis for pleural fluid analysis
Obtain high-resolution CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – In a patient with asbestos exposure, progressive dyspnea, and a new unilateral pleural effusion, diagnostic thoracentesis is indicated to evaluate for malignant mesothelioma or metastatic lung carcinoma. This procedure provides both therapeutic relief and essential cytologic information.

B) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT can characterize parenchymal fibrosis and pleural plaques, but does not address the immediate need to evaluate the cause of dyspnea.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence of infection (no fever, purulent sputum, or infiltrate). Empiric antibiotics are inappropriate when the clinical picture suggests a chronic occupational disease rather than pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography would be appropriate for assessing pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale as complications of advanced asbestosis, but evaluation of the pleural effusion takes priority given the constitutional symptoms and malignancy risk.

E) INCORRECT:

While heart failure can cause pleural effusion, the presence of pleural plaques and a long history of asbestos exposure points to a pulmonary rather than cardiac etiology.

questions.text: A 72-year-old former demolition contractor presents to the ED with progressive shortness of breath over several months, now worse with minimal exertion. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. Vital signs are BP, 138/78 mm Hg; P, 94; R, 22; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); oxygen saturation, 91% on room air. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lower lobe reticular opacities and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate empiric bronchodilator therapy and arrange outpatient follow-up for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Obtain high-resolution CT and arrange pulmonary consultation
Admit for inpatient evaluation of possible pneumonia
Order D-dimer and CT pulmonary angiography to exclude pulmonary embolism
Begin empiric corticosteroids for presumed inflammatory pneumonitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a smoking history, the imaging findings of interstitial fibrosis and pleural plaques are not consistent with COPD. Treating empirically for airflow obstruction would delay recognition of fibrotic lung disease.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Chronic dyspnea with restrictive findings and pleural plaques in a patient with prior asbestos exposure suggests asbestosis. High-resolution CT confirms the pattern and severity of fibrosis, while pulmonary referral ensures appropriate follow-up and malignancy screening.

C) INCORRECT:

The absence of fever, leukocytosis, or focal consolidation argues against infection. Hospital admission for presumed pneumonia would be inappropriate when the presentation reflects chronic interstitial disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism presents acutely with pleuritic pain or abrupt hypoxemia, not progressive dyspnea and chronic radiographic changes. CT angiography would expose the patient to unnecessary contrast without diagnostic value here.

E) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is fibrotic, not inflammatory; corticosteroids have no proven benefit and can cause adverse metabolic effects.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a three-month history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion and a dull ache in his right chest. He worked in building demolition and renovation for 40 years before retiring. On examination, he is afebrile. There are decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the right lower lung field. A chest radiograph confirms a large, right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed, and analysis of the pleural fluid reveals a hemorrhagic, exudative effusion with lymphocytic predominance. Cytology is negative for malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for malignant mesothelioma. The most significant clue is the extensive occupational asbestos exposure from his work in demolition and renovation. Mesothelioma typically has a long latency period of 20 to 40 years. Clinically, it presents insidiously with dyspnea, nonpleuritic chest pain, and a large, unilateral exudative pleural effusion. The pleural fluid is often hemorrhagic and lymphocytic-predominant, as seen here. A crucial diagnostic point is that pleural fluid cytology has low sensitivity (around 60%) for mesothelioma, and a negative result does not rule it out. Diagnosis often requires video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) with pleural biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

While a pulmonary embolism can cause dyspnea, chest pain, and an exudative pleural effusion that may be hemorrhagic, the clinical course is typically acute. This patient's three-month history of progressive symptoms is not consistent with a new pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

A complicated parapneumonic effusion is an exudative collection of fluid in the pleural space that results from an adjacent pneumonia. This diagnosis is unlikely given the three-month progressive history, absence of fever, and lymphocytic predominance in the pleural fluid. A parapneumonic effusion typically has an acute onset and is neutrophilic.

D) INCORRECT:

Metastatic adenocarcinoma, particularly from the lung, is the most common cause of malignant pleural effusion and can present with an exudative, hemorrhagic, and lymphocytic-predominant fluid. However, the 40-year history of intense asbestos exposure makes a different diagnosis more likely in this particular patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous pleurisy can cause a subacute presentation with a lymphocytic-predominant exudative effusion. However, patients typically have systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats, which are absent here. Furthermore, tuberculous effusions are characteristically straw-colored, not hemorrhagic.
questions.hint: A long history of asbestos exposure is the primary risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dull, aching pain in his right chest. He reports an unintentional 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over this period. He has worked as a pipefitter in naval shipyards for over 30 years. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit 15 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the right lower lung field. A chest radiograph reveals a large, right-sided pleural effusion. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of progressive shortness of breath, dull, aching pain in his chest, and weight loss, physical examination findings, and characteristic imaging findings of a large, unilateral pleural effusion and pleural thickening are consistent with malignant mesothelioma. This tumor arises from the mesothelial cells of the pleura and is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, which is likely due to his work as a shipyard pipefitter. There is typically a long latency period of 20 to 40 years between exposure and symptom onset. While smoking is a risk factor for bronchogenic carcinoma, it is not an independent risk factor for mesothelioma.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous pleurisy can cause a unilateral pleural effusion, chest pain, and weight loss. However, the radiographic finding of irregular pleural thickening is not typical for tuberculous pleurisy, which usually presents with a simple effusion and smooth pleural enhancement on contrast-enhanced CT.

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma is strongly associated with smoking and can present with constitutional symptoms. However, it is typically a central tumor arising from the bronchi, and its classic presentation includes hemoptysis and a hilar mass on imaging. The findings of a large pleural effusion and pleural thickening are not the characteristic radiographic features of squamous cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient could have had asbestosis due to his previous profession. Additionally, asbestosis may manifest with progressive dyspnea and imaging findings of pleural thickening. However, given this patient's weight loss, chest pain, and pleural effusion, a different diagnosis is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and can present with dyspnea, weight loss, and a malignant pleural effusion. However, it typically arises from the lung parenchyma and appears as a peripheral nodule or mass on imaging, in contrast to the irregular thickening of the pleura seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows circumferential pleural thickening alongside a right unilateral pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office with a 5-year history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion and a nonproductive cough. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and bibasilar, end-inspiratory crackles. A CT scan of the chest shows interstitial fibrosis with subpleural honeycombing and multiple calcified pleural plaques. Further inquiry into which of the following is most likely to identify the underlying cause of his condition?

choices.text: A career in underground coal mining

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Underground coal mining leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis. Radiographic findings typically show small, rounded opacities (coal macules) in the upper lung zones, which can progress to massive fibrosis. However, coal workers' pneumoconiosis does not cause the calcified pleural plaques that are a key feature of this patient's CT scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Raising pigeons can lead to exposure to avian antigens, causing hypersensitivity pneumonitis (bird fancier's lung). Although chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in pulmonary fibrosis, its characteristic CT findings include centrilobular nodules, ground-glass opacities, and air trapping. It does not cause calcified pleural plaques.

C) CORRECT:

Asbestosis is a form of pulmonary fibrosis caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, most commonly affecting individuals with a history of occupational exposure in industries such as shipbuilding, construction, insulation, and automotive manufacturing. Asbestos was widely used for insulation and fireproofing in naval shipyards and related industries. The disease typically presents decades after exposure (20–30 years) with progressive exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, digital clubbing, and characteristic imaging findings, including lower-lobe predominant interstitial fibrosis, honeycombing, and calcified pleural plaques. Smoking significantly increases the risk of bronchogenic carcinoma in affected individuals. The diagnosis relies on clinical history, radiographic evidence, and exclusion of other causes of interstitial lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Sandblasting is associated with exposure to silica dust, which causes silicosis. Although silicosis can cause progressive pulmonary fibrosis, its characteristic radiographic findings include multiple small, rounded opacities predominantly in the upper lung zones and eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes. Silicosis does not cause the calcified pleural plaques seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Working in the aerospace industry can involve exposure to beryllium, leading to chronic berylliosis. This is a granulomatous lung disease that can mimic sarcoidosis, often manifesting with hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial infiltrates that can progress to fibrosis. However, berylliosis is not characterized by the presence of calcified pleural plaques.
questions.hint: Calcified pleural plaques on chest CT are highly characteristic of asbestosis and are regarded as a reliable marker of prior asbestos exposure.
